bioghist.p: The University Hospitals have a long tradition of supplying research beds for detailed patient studies. In accordance with this tradition, in 1959, when renovations of University Hospital vacated a large amount of space on the ground floor, a faculty committee recommended that the space be used for research beds. In June 1959 the United States Congress recommended to the National Institutes of Health (NIH) that it fund the establishment of research bed facilities in academic institutions throughout the country. This combination of faculty recommendation and Congressional will led to the establishment of a NIH-funded, Clinical Research Center at University Hospital in May 1962.

Equipped with 16 inpatient beds and 8 outpatient beds, the Center represents an unusually stable environment where a specially trained nursing and dietetic staff, supported by dedicated laboratory facilities, can obtain precise control of clinical procedures and carefully observed patient reaction. To make use of the facility, a researcher must submit a written protocol explaining the nature of the experiment, its specific methodology and the likely results. The Center's Operating Subcommittee meets regularly to consider the protocols, as well as establish priorities and oversee the Center's daily operations. Overall responsibility for the Center's activities resides with the Policy Committee.

Subsequent grants from the NIH have allowed the Center to continue in operation for over thirty years. Copies of protocols are sent to NIH as part of the competing renewal grant report to NIH each year. The Center must submit a non-competing grant report to NIH each year. In 1992 the name of the Center was changed to General Clinical Research Center.

During 1999, over 150 individual adult and pediatric research studies were active at the Center, involving collaborations between over 400 investigators resulting in a total of 1828 GCRC-funded and 153 industry-sponsored inpatient days, and 3134 GCRC-funded outpatient visits. Some areas of research included: Alzheimer's, AIDS, cancer, depression, dermatology, diabetes, epilepsy, gene therapy, growth disorders, heart disease, hypertension, intestinal hormones, kidney disease, menopause, and obesity.

arrangement.p: The General Clinical Research Center records were received in three main accessions in 1985 (boxes 1-8), a set of accessions 1989-1996 (boxes 9-26) and a 2002 accession (box27-47). The records are organize in two main series, Program Files and Project Files (Protocols). Each of the series is divided into subseries reflecting the various accessions.

scopecontent.p: The records of the General Clinical Research Center consist of both administrative files and records of clinical experiments. They include reports, correspondence, grant files, committee records and other administrative files and records research protocols and supporting documents for individual research projects.

scopecontent.p: The Program Files series contains records created through the administration of the Center. The series includes a history, annual progress reports, committee records, construction records, correspondence, and grant applications. The series is organized in three subseries reflecting the accession in which records were received.

The 1959-1985 subseries includes a history file is comprised of a reprint of an article from The University of Michigan Medical Center Journal entitled, "The Clinical Research Unit of the University of Michigan Medical Center." The annual progress reports represent the Center's annual accounting to NIH and are the single most complete set of papers documenting the Center. The committee records contain minutes of both the Operating Subcommittee and the Policy Committee. The Operating Subcommittee's minutes are relatively complete from 1962 to 1975 and include a brief summary of virtually all protocols submitted for consideration. The Policy Committee records are strongest for the years 1961 to 1963. Although the minutes continue to 1977, they are very scattered after the first three years. The construction records include materials related to the construction of a metabolic unit, a general research ward, and clinical research laboratories. Correspondence is almost exclusively with NIH regarding funding. Copies of grant applications are usually included. Content of the grant application files is often redundant of the correspondence files. It is differentiated, however, in that it is largely made up of the most significant grant applications.

did.unittitle: Correspondence (primarily with National Institutes of Health)

scopecontent.p: The Program Files, 1976-1995 subseries is comprised of annual progress reports, committee records, and grant applications. All three files continue those from the previous accession. Committee records contain minutes of the Operating Subcommittee which begin in 1976 and continue the run of minutes from the first accession. The grant applications contain projected budget figures, equipment costs, and copies of active protocols. The applications continue the run from the first accession.

Program Files, 1979-1999 subseries includes annual progress reports, 1990-1994, and committee minutes and records including the Operating Subcommittee, 1987-1997, GCRC Advisory Committee, 1998-1999, and annual Policy Committee, 1978-1996. Other administrative material includes floor plans and applications for a gene therapy human applications lab. The folder "Racial/Ethnic Information" gives statistical profiles of the racial composition of GCRC patients, 1990-1994.

The Project Files series represents research protocols approved by the Operating Subcommittee. The series is subdivided into subseries reflecting the varius accession in which records were received. The protocols are arranged in numerical sequence. The sequence in a subseries may be incomplete both because of the absence of early protocols and because the Center retained protocols that governed active research projects.

The protocol files contain information regarding individual clinical experiments, or protocols. These files are arranged in ascending numerical order by protocol number. The records for each protocol are comprised of a brief summary; a detailed narrative of the plan of work, budget, personnel and expected results; reviewers' comments; and merit evaluations by the Operating Subcommittee. There are gaps in the range of protocols in this series because some protocols remain active and are retained by the Center. Some of the protocols fill in gaps found in the protocol series in the first accession, others contain materials which supplement protocol material found in the first accession. Both accessions should be consulted to insure that all material for a given protocol has been examined.

There is no subject access to the protocols. There is, however, a form of access by name of the principal investigator. An alphabetical listing of principal investigators with a cross reference to their individual protocol numbers and titles can be found in the index section of the grant application for 1985-1990 and in the table of contents section of the grant applications for 1990-1995 and 1995-2000 (see discussion of Program Files above).

The Protocol Summaries files (boxes 12-13), contain brief summaries for protocols 1-278 which were removed and kept separate from the rest of the file by the Center's personnel. These summaries are one or two page descriptions of the protocol's purpose, plan of work and key personnel, and the decision of the Operating Subcommittee regarding the protocol's merits.

scopecontent.p: Clinical Associate Physician (CAP) and Minority Clinical Associate Physician (MCAP) program records, 1986-1996, include research applications, evaluations, and letters of recommendation (including some from Francis Collins) pertaining to this NIH program which supplied salary and benefits for three years to junior faculty interested in training in clinical research.
